REVIEW_BODY:
Wild Wild Wet reopens. With many more rides and a bigger space._x000D_
_x000D_
I had the opportunity to bring my 2 pre-teen boys during the June school holidays. It opens at around 10am during the school holidays (they call it the Peak period)._x000D_
_x000D_
Bought their family combo - $92 (3 adults and 1 child below 13 years old). They usually have promo prices during school holidays - be sure to ask. If u are an NTUC card members, they have different prices for u too._x000D_
_x000D_
If u are not the swimmer-parents (like me & hubby), go to the office which is situated near the boarding gates and rent a tent (cavana). It costs u $80 (for whole day rent under NTUC card; normal peak price is $90). It can fit 4 persons. It has a fridge; 2 2-seater sofa, a lazy seat and a big float. U will be given 4 towels which u need to send back aft ur stay._x000D_
_x000D_
They also have a 6-persons tent which costs around $110 for peak period (NTUC card price)._x000D_
_x000D_
Both offers comes with snacks like hot wings and fries (with can drinks), and u can request for the time to be served._x000D_
_x000D_
The kids enjoyed different pools; from baby pools, lazy river to ooo-la-la and jacuzzi._x000D_
_x000D_
Muslim patrons can go out of the Wild Wild Wet to do their prayers at E-hub musollas and re-enter the place again._x000D_
_x000D_
Family friendly, kids'friendly & Muslim friendly._x000D_
_x000D_
I'll be back. This time with my swimming burqa!
ADDRESS: 1 Pasir Ris Close E!Hub@Downtown East, Singapore 519599, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: A great place to relax enjoy the view!
REVIEW_BODY: We often go for a walk along the waterfront promenade when in Singapore. There are some nice cafe's and restaurants in the area and we sometimes call in and have some refreshments at the Fullerton Bay Hotel and sit out on the front veranda and enjoy the views of the waterfront area. Along the promenade you will see the Merlion; three interesting; huge flower structures which are ideal for a good photo; two silver coloured panda bears sitting on the lawn near the Fullerton Bay Hotel; people exercising in groups in the park area and along the waterfront walk, and beautiful views day and night. As you walk closer to the Marina Bay Sands hotel coming from the Merlion area you will see some giant fans which also double as weather protection. These are solar powered and only come on when someone comes near them...very clever! Close to those fans is an entrance to underground shops and cafes. It goes for miles underground.
ADDRESS: Singapore, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: A unique way to look at wildlife
REVIEW_BODY:
We visired thenight safari after we visited the zoo._x000D_
_x000D_
Likes_x000D_

REVIEW_BODY: This is a must see place when in Singapore. There are two domes: the Cloud Forest and the Flower Dome plus a Skyway and themed outdoor gardens. The Cloud Forest is as the name implies and multi story high glasshouse with a huge waterfall in it and thousands of plants from all over the word. The flower dome was having an orchid extravaganza when I was there and was gloriously colorful. The Skyway allows you to look out over Singapore 360 degrees. Take your camera as there are 100s of photos opportunities. The overall effect reminded me a little of "Elven" designs as per Lord of the Rings and definitely a little bit out of this world. The Gardens are easily accessed by MRT, Bus or taxi. There is a huge shopping centre within walking distance when you walk through Marina Bay Sands - the iconic hotel with the boat on the top of it.

REVIEW_BODY:
Har Paw Villa is a unique theme park based on the Chinese mythology, folklore, legends, history, and illustrations of various aspects of Confucianism and Buddhism. The most famous part of Har Paw Villa is the 10 courts of Hell. Har Paw Villa is easily accessible by the Har Paw Villa MRT, and it admission is free. The park is opened from 9am to 7pm while the 10 courts of Hell closes at 5.30pm._x000D_
_x000D_

REVIEW_BODY: Fun fact. Walking through the tree-covered walkways in MacRitchie reservoir is really pleasant, several degrees cooler than the city. Also, we encountered a monkey on the bridge, who stalked past us and hired menacingly at my daughter, when she studied him too closely. REVIEW_BODY:
A must visit for tourists. The Gardens is huge and covers several different areas. I personally prefer to explore the free area close to evening time as it would be much cooler and the lighting on the super tree is superb._x000D_
_x000D_
The 2 paid domes are called the flower dome and cloud dome. As the name suggests, the flower dome is decorated with different types of flowers and it is beautiful. They also have different kind of events running from time to time and they were having the Matsuri Sakura event. I was expecting more Sakura but hey at least I got to see some._x000D_
_x000D_
The cloud dome is a favorite. I love the waterfalls and the towering wall of plants. It is truly majestic and breath taking. This area requires a lot of climbing although there are lifts. The wait time is long though._x000D_
_x000D_
The domes have a very strict no food and drink inside them so when travelling with the kids, plan it so they do not go in hungry. Once entered, the paths are one way towards the exit and there are no re-entries._x000D_
_x000D_
The children can also visit the children's garden for some water fun._x000D_
_x000D_
Overall, I recommend spending half a day to fully explore the park at a slow pace.

Once you have purchased tickets, you can choose to be taken round by a guide (free of charge- they are all highly trained volunteers), or stroll around by yourself, at your own pace._x000D_
A great place for all ages._x000D_
There is a cafe inside which sells delicious cakes - but if you walk round the corner there is a Janice Wong cafe for chocolate lovers (also very tasty lunch menu!).
ADDRESS: 93 Stamford Road National Museum of Singapore, Singapore 178897, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: One of the Most Beautiful in the World
REVIEW_BODY: A friend and native Singaporean told me on my first visit that the most magical moment I could have in town would be to walk in the Botanic Gardens just before sunrise. Since then I have made a point to do just this on each trip, and my latest visit (in August) proved that it still is true. You can take the metro (it opens by 5:30 am), walk, or taxi there, and the gates are open around 5 am. This peaceful time actually becomes a symphony, as you walk through the special gardens (the Ginger Garden is one of my favorites), around the lakes, and listen to the birds rise up in song. People practicing tai chi and yoga soon join them, and you'll share the path with runners and walkers getting exercise before the heat of the day begins. Look for the hidden sculptures as well, and the Heritage Trees scattered throughout the park. Yes, a magical place, and free to visit.
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Road, Singapore 259 569, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: An Awe-Inspiring Visit to The Intan!
REVIEW_BODY: The visit to The Intan on 30 Sept was totally awe-inspiring. The homely museum in Joo Chiat brings the Peranakan culture & heritage to life which makes the experience unique unlike the visits to the other museums. The history shared by the passionate and hospitable host, Alvin Yapp, was enriching and eye-opening. Most of all, the authentic Peranakan delicacies prepared by his mum & aunt were awesome. The Intan is a must-visit destination in Singapore.

REVIEW_BODY:
Orchard Road is basically the shopping district of Singapore. It has both upmarket outlets such as Tiffany and co, Gucci, Rolex, Luis Vuitton and so on as well as some market areas usually at street level where you can get a bargain._x000D_
The street is spotless and crowded so be prepared to spend a day or two jostling through the various shopping centres and stores._x000D_
There are banks and ATMs, money chengers, bars, restaurants,street vendors (pizza and kebab caravans) coffee shops._x000D_
If that isn't enough for you then you call always call in to the various massage locations (in Orchard Road) many of which are open 24 hours._x000D_
Buses are continuously going up and down Orchard Road as are taxis so you can always get there and back to your hotel no matter where you are staying._x000D_
Many of the shops are open until 11.00 pm so there is always enough time to wander through the various locations._x000D_
There are also tailors located on Orchard Road who will custom make clothing for you, in fact my wife picked up a custom made silk jacket for work for only $350 SGD._x000D_
There are plenty of seven eleven stores on Orchard Road for those that just want a drink or a snack._x000D_
Orchard Road is something that the girls will revel in whereas for us guys there is always a bar or two that we can hide in while the girls do their thing.
ADDRESS: Singapore, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Total waste of time (5 hours for 30mins)
REVIEW_BODY:
As seasoned travellers we occasionally get things wrong and this was one of them, not sure why because I dislike zoos in principal although do recognise the job that they do with endangered species._x000D_
Anyhow it had been recommended by a few friends and so without reading up about we bought a "tour" through the hotel conceige including collection and return to our hotel._x000D_
The "collector" arrived 30 minutes than we were expecting, a total of two coach changes and we were on our way._x000D_
Our tickets were "priority" boarding so no lines to board the tram which promised a 40 minute tour. Now admitantly I did not time the tour but but on the basis of when we left and the time left to kill afterwards I would guess at around 30 minutes was nearer the truth._x000D_
It could have well been short due to the fact that we saw very few animals and those that we did see were so far away, the tram stops for very short periods to view and then moves on whether we are ready or not._x000D_
The only real viewing was of the tiger which of course is behind glass and acting very stressed pacing across the enclosure as they do when stressed. Did not enjoy._x000D_
There are walks to be taken through some of the enclosures and again due to my wifes walking issues we were unable to avail ourselves of these so cannot comment._x000D_
The only other thing to pass the time until your return coach arrives is either eat or queue for a 800 seat theater with no guarantee of a seat when you get to the end!_x000D_
As far we could establish they make no concessions for disabled people to attend the show._x000D_
They do not allow coaches to park on the drop off zone and for unkown reasons we managed to miss our planned return coach, thankfully their is a 6SS$ option to get back which departs on the hour to town hotel drop offs._x000D_
Believe me there are a lot more things to do in Singapore than waste your money and more importantly time on this.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore
clean_text: season traveller occasionally get thing wrong one not sure dislike zoo principal although recognise job endanger speciesxd anyhow recommend friend without reading bought tour hotel conceige include collection return hotelxd collector arrive minute expect total two coach change wayxd ticket priority boarding line board tram promise minute tour admitantly not time tour basis left time left kill afterwards would guess around minute nearer truthxd could well short due fact saw animal see far away tram stop short period view move whether ready notxd real view tiger course behind glass act stress pace across enclosure stress not enjoyxd walk take enclosure due wife walk issue unable avail can not commentxd thing pas time return coach arrives either eat queue seat theater guarantee seat get endxd far could establish make concession disabled people attend showxd not allow coach park drop zone unkown reason manage miss plan return coach thankfully s option get back departs hour town hotel drop offsxd believe lot thing singapore waste money importantly time

REVIEW_BODY:
If you are visiting Singapore, I hope one of your destinations is Garden By The Bay. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s one of the most popular destinations in Singapore._x000D_
_x000D_
You can go to Garden By The Bay by using MRT. When you arrive at Bayfront station, take the exit B. Then walk in the Underground Linkway and cross the Dragonfly Bridge to reach Gardens By The Bay. It only took about 3 Ã¢â‚¬â€œ 5 minutes of walking._x000D_
_x000D_
As soon as you arrived, buy the ticket because if you wait, there will be more people. The ticket price for adult cost about 28 Singapore Dollars and for kid cost about 15 Singapore Dollars. The ticket is for visiting 2 places, the Flower Dome and the Cloud Forest._x000D_
_x000D_
You should also buy the shuttle bus ticket because if you walk, your legs might hurt. The ticket cost about 2 Singapore Dollars and you can use it two times. It may seem a little expensive, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s worth it._x000D_
_x000D_
I recommend you to visit the Flower Dome first so you can learn about many plants species. The Flower Dome contains diverse species of plant and some can be found in the picture that I had attached below._x000D_
_x000D_
One cons of the dome is that, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s kind of smelly. Some plants would dried up and cause the smell to form. If you are plan on taking your kids, you might consider asking them if they are fine with the smell because itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s quite strong._x000D_
_x000D_
The next stop is the Cloud Forest. The Cloud Forest contains less type of plants but, in my opinion, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s better than the Flower Dome. When you enter the Cloud Forest, you would see a huge waterfall. There would be water vapor in the air and that would freshen you._x000D_
_x000D_
Then you can use the elevator to go to the top. When you reached the top, you can walk on the walkway and learned about the species of plants that are grown in tropical highlands. You would feel like walking through the cloud._x000D_
_x000D_
To conclude, Garden By The Bay is one of the best places to visit in Singapore. If Garden By The Bay is not on your tour list, add them now.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
The National Orchid Garden is within the confines of the Botanic Gardens and easily accessible by MRT. I don't think I can convey in words how beautiful this orchid garden is. Mind you orchids are one of my favourite flowers so I guess that I am somewhat biased. Never before have I seen so many different colours, sizes and shapes of orchids all together in one area. But it is not just the orchids, but also the supporting greenery, statues, pathways, seats, walls, arches, water features, etc that bring the whole thing together to form a cohesive whole that is so very pleasing to the eye._x000D_
They have a gift shop, which also sells some snack type things, and toilets are right next door. All this for just $1 for Seniors and I think $5 for others; worth every cent.

REVIEW_BODY:
We were in Singapore for two days, and followed the crowds to Gardens by the Bay. The temperate dome is a great achievement, but if you've visited Spain or Australia or South Africa, you will have seen all the trees and plants._x000D_
The recreation of the mountainous rain forest, on the other hand, does give an experience few will see in real life - and the waterfall is spectacular._x000D_
Still have mixed views about creating an artifice like this though - reminded me of banana growing in Chatsworth House in the 18th century; impressive achievement, but why?

REVIEW_BODY:
If you get a chance, look up the building of MBS on YouTube to give you a little more appreciation for this phenomenal structure. The infinity pool at Skypark was on my bucket list and it did not disappoint._x000D_
NOTE: You need to be a hotel guest of MBS to enjoy the pool. (Each person needs to have their own hotel key card to enter.)_x000D_
The views from there are spectacular. There are also nice views on the opposite side, from the hot tubs. The pool water can be cold once the sun goes down, but feels really good when sunny. However, at night, you get a decent view of the nightly light show by the bay. Don't forget to take your token selfie at the pool!_x000D_
_x000D_
There are also 2 restaurants up there- Lavo and Spago. Lavo was not really my taste, but Spago offered a good breakfast. We wanted to go for dinner, but never made it._x000D_
_x000D_
You can also pay to go to the observation deck, but we never did that since we were staying at the hotel. At night, there is a club up there, which seemed quite popular. We didn't go because that's not really our thing._x000D_
_x000D_
If you're in Singapore, MBS Skypark is a must-see. Enjoy!
ADDRESS: 10 Bayfront Avenue | Level 57, Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Singapore 018956, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Nice well-maintained zoo, very poor queue management
REVIEW_BODY: I want to give this place a higher rating but they definitely need to improve their queue management. We bought tickets via Klook but it took us almost an hour to enter after they've opened the gates - the queue was very long (our tickets were for the 8:15 PM entry). We were supposed to line up for the tram but after being in line for several minutes and seeing how long the queue was, my husband decided that we should just do the walking trail. This turned out to be a good decision. This allowed us to go around the park and see the animals up close. The zoo seems well maintained and has a good selection of animals - very enjoyable particularly for young kids. We brought a stroller for our 5 year old son, so we were able to move him around quickly when he would tire from walking. While we enjoyed the walking trail, I was also concerned during this time if we will be able to catch the tram and see the show before the night was over. After going around for almost an hour to complete the walking trail, we were able to line up fairly quickly for the tram ride. At this time though, we had already missed the creatures of the night show (930 PM show) and the park was nearing closing time (already past 10 PM). From our experience, if you enter at 815 PM, you will not be able to see all the attractions - in our case, we just did the walking trail and tram but missed the show. The zoo needs to manage their queues better, maybe limit the tickets sold so their guests can still get a good solid experience and not feel like they need to be rushing to cover the entire place and enjoy all the attractions. Or maybe they can also adjust the timings so the park closes at a slightly later time and people can enjoy the place better. In terms of customer service, I didn't find the attendants very friendly, some were unsmiling or curt when you ask them questions. Suggest better training for them as well - they are part of the experience.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Singapore Flyer should be on your list of must-dos when you visit Singapore._x000D_
_x000D_
We went in August 2017 and had taken the viator tickets package so did not have to stand in the ticket queue. Pram Friendly right up to the entrance which is on a higher level. There's a security checkpoint where you need to leave the pram and other big bags. We went during the afternoon and there was a queue at the boarding post so it took us about 30 mins to board the flyer._x000D_
_x000D_
There were about 10 of us in a capsule which can accommodate upto 20. Very spacious and air conditioned. The view was excellent and the speed is simply perfect - neither too fast nor too slow. They make an announcement when your capsule is at the peak and you have ample time to take photos and capture the view!_x000D_
_x000D_
All exits to tourist spots in Singapore are through Gift Shops and this was no exception. There are eating joints at the ground level and taxi stand is right in front
ADDRESS: 30 Raffles Avenue, Singapore 039803, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: This is definitely worth a visit, not only for those who are into architecture and visual art, but also anybody. A beautiful space built in the old City Hall and Supreme Court Buildings. There are many exhibitions, ranging from ancient to modern time of Singapore and South East Asia. I explored various kinds of paintings and sculptures, each having its own beauty. The information provided was helpful, and the staff was also very friendly. On the other hand, the directions and the location of each exhibition on the map was quite confusing. Despite having the map, I still have a hard time getting to the places I wanted. So I suggest that you should take a guided tour if this is your first time here. In conclusion, this is really an enjoyable experience, and I highly recommend you paying a visit.
ADDRESS: 1 St. Andrew's Road #01-01 National Gallery Singapore, Singapore 178957, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Recommend getting tickets online as entry goes by timing. The queues may look a bit intimidating but the Night Safari folks are super nice, helpful, and efficient! We arrived at 7pm, had dinner, and then lined up for our 8.15pm entry._x000D_
_x000D_
Would definitely recommend walking as some animals take awhile to warm up and actually even appear._x000D_
_x000D_
Quite a number of tourists, sometimes they can get quite loud but if you just chill and wait it out, they'll leave (they're usually on a schedule so they can't stay too long anyway)_x000D_
_x000D_
Saw some really inconsiderate guests who kept flashing phone torchlights, actual torchlights, and camera flashes...DO NOT be That Guest, please._x000D_
_x000D_
But otherwise, the whole walking experience, the animals, the atmosphere, even the mozzie situation (almost NONE), and the staff were SUPER. Definitely take your time when you go. We were the last patrons to leave the park and by the time 11pm hit, we could really take in everything at an amazing pace and felt really good about our whole experience:) We actually covered all the walking trails too even though we were practically strolling!_x000D_
_x000D_
P/S: beware of flying squirrels pooping! You'll know if they're nearby;)

REVIEW_BODY: Instead of heading to Garden by the Bay, you should actually head to this Barrage for the best view of Singapore cityscape. Whereas you have got to pay SG$25 to enter any one of the glass canopy at Garden by the Bay, entrance to the Barrage is FREE! There's a green above the dam and that's where expat and local families congregate to have picnic and to fly kites on weekends. The place is pleasant to visit with soft wind billowing from the ocean. In the evening, the place is a popular haunt for lovers to congregate, fellow friends to gather and to enjoy the view together, and even students coming here to make use of the ample space below to rehearse upon their dance and so forth. This is actually a place that you get to see the interaction between locals and international visitors. One amazing feat about this Barrage is that there's hardly any mosquitoes day and night, and that such a small place is able to process water for three quarter of the island's population. It's truly an amazing feat. Should you have a bike, there's a new trail that enables you to cycle all the way to East Coast. You can also do this in absolute safety as CCTV is everywhere in Singapore. Talking about the most underrated tourist attraction, this will be it. Highly recommended!
ADDRESS: 8 Marina Gardens Drive Marina Barrage, Singapore 018951, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: There is urban planning and then there is Singapore...
REVIEW_BODY:
It's a must visit for anybody who wants to understand and marvel at Singapore's urban planning achievements. There is no city in the world that is so forward looking and progressive with its own design trying to strike a balance between functionality, efficiency, affordability and environmental beauty of its living spaces. Truly astonishing when you understand that it was only 50 years ago since Singapore kickstarted its urban development into overdrive._x000D_
_x000D_
There is a huge 1:400 scaled model of the city, plus lots of exhibits documenting the different stages in the city development, starting with public housing projects and culminating with its latest efforts around the Marina Bay and its 'Garden City' projects throughout the whole city... Plenty of architectural plans and drawings of the many famous structures in Singapore and around the world designed by Singapore's architectural firms. Lots of models of famous buildings, audiovisual presentations... Future plans... Very impressive and immersive..._x000D_
_x000D_
Very much recommended for anybody who visits Singapore. One of my favorites!!! And it's FREE to visit;)_x000D_
_x000D_
See all of my pictures to get a better sense and preview of this superb urban planning museum.
ADDRESS: 45 Maxwell Road The Ura Centre | The URA Centre, Level 2, Singapore 069118, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Well designed park, almost all animals were visible
REVIEW_BODY: We spent a great day at the zoo, it took app. 6 hours to view the whole thing. I'm probably a slow visitor, who enjoys watching the animals in a leisurely pace. It's definitely the best of the "traditional" zoos I have visited so far, with good habitats where the animals are visible and free ranging non-dangerous animals (e.g. small monkeys). I highly recommend it to people who spend lots of time in Singapore, or to people on short visits who have been to few or no zoos before (and would like to see some animals). Of the 4 animals parks in Singapore I actually only rank it no. 3 (Night Safari and River Safari surpassing it), because I find it a bit big (compared to the River Safari), and because I have seen many of the animals before (both River and Night Safari having non-traditional animals), but it is definitely worth a visit if you have the time! You can buy a 4-park hopper ticket to experience all the parks (one entry per park valid for 7days) or you can buy a 2-park ticket where you can choose which parks to visit. Make sure to bring a water bottle, as the park has water stations to fill it up. We had lunch at Ah Meng and they had a wide selection of cuisines (western, Chinese, Indian etc.) and was not wildly expensive (app. 12$ per dish). The grey kangaroo habitat was amazing: when we were there the kangaroo crossed the walking path right between a bunch of people to get to the shaded side, so cute! Also the polar bear was impressive, it's so huge! A lot of people were also hanging out there to enjoy the AC. The white tiger is definitely also worth a visit, it's beautiful. And the Borneoan Orangutan was so cool, it apparently often sits in it's favorite spot which is right up against the glass, looking out at people. The zoo offers a free shuttle service to (and I assume from) Khatib MRT station (red line), but it may only be on Sunday's and public holidays. All in all a day well spent, and worth the price (we bought the 4-park ticket, which will save you 50% of single ticket prices, in addition if you buy the ticket online you save another 10%).
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: The longest pedestrian bridge in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY:
It was in Madrid years ago that we got to see our first helix bridge, the second is in Singapore. The design of the bridge is based on the structure of DNA and at 280 metres long is the longest pedestrian bridge in Singapore. The bridge connects Marina Bay Sands to the City Hall area and provides great views over the river back towards the CBD._x000D_
_x000D_
Before crossing over to Marina Bay Sands we stopped for an icecream from a mobile cart and checked out an art installation wall titled 'Friendship' which showcases images of over 3000 athletes who formed friendships during the Singapore 2010 Youth Olympic Games. There's also a nice small garden next door with outdoor art installations.
ADDRESS: Linking between Marina Bay and Marina Centre, Singapore 038981, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Cloud Forest is one of two huge biodomes in Singapore's Gardens by the Bay._x000D_
_x000D_
It is an eight-stores high glass greenhouse maintained at a constant temperature and humidity to simulate the ideal conditions for mountain top flora to flourish._x000D_
_x000D_
You catch a lift to the top them walk down a spiraling ramp, through various levels of mountain trees, bushes, shrubs, plants, flowers, ferns and mosses._x000D_
_x000D_
Big waterfalls add to the visual effect and also hel to maintain humidity levels._x000D_
_x000D_
A double ticket giving admission to both biodomes - the other is the Flower Dome - is S$33 for foreigners.

REVIEW_BODY: What a delightful park to visit Ã¢â‚¬â€œ an educational experience for the whole family! To get the lay of the land, we began our visit by taking the tram tour first and then decided which areas were of greatest interest. We were amazed and delighted not only by the array of birds we found in the park Ã¢â‚¬â€œ everything from owls and parakeets to pelicans and flamingos Ã¢â‚¬â€œ but by the cleanliness of the grounds and cages as well. Visit the Breeding and Research Center to learn about egg size, number of eggs each bird lays per year, how newborns are cared for by the park, and how aquatic birds are prepared for release into various exhibits! The bird shows are great fun for children and adults alike. Absolutely amazing! Visiting this park does involve a lot of walking, which can be tiring in humid tropical weather. Wear good walking shoes, and take along bottled water!

After spending over two hours in th domes we saw the 7:45 light show which was spectacular. We had viewed this the previous evening from the 57th floor of Marina Bay Sands and thought ho hum, noting special but our guide advised us that we needed to be at ground level amongst the trees to appreciate it and she was right. REVIEW_BODY:
Greetings Readers, Salty and Mrs Kroc are here in Singapore for a winter break from shaking down Australian Bogans for the bank to take in the spectacular flowers at the Garden Festival. We thought that we would also pay a visit to the night safari having been to the Singapore Zoo previously during the day and really enjoyed ourselves. This outstanding institution is at the vanguard of animal conservation, and particularly of the many endangered primates in this part of the world._x000D_
_x000D_
However, I can only describe our interaction with the night safari as an unmitigated disaster and an almost complete waste of $100. Things began well enough, we booked an online tour with City Tours figuring this would be the easiest way to get out to the zoo from where we are staying on Orchard Road. This was simple enough, and we had a good start with the shuttle van collecting us promptly at 5:45pm. We spent the next 40 minutes weaving our way through various neighbourhoods, stopping and waiting for patrons who never bothered to turn up. Eventually, we got down to the Singapore Flyer at 6:20pm. This seems like a long ride,but then we waited another 15 minutes for a shuttle driver to arrive and collect the 8 of us who had bothered to turn up._x000D_
_x000D_
Here began yet a stranger odyssey as, despite having a full van, we weaved our way through downtown streets stopping at two more hotels, where our second driver disembarked and engaged in animated discussions with staff at these hotels after which he returned to the car and eventually got us on the PIE to Lake Mandai. I have no idea way we made these stops,though it cost us another 20 minutes in delays, and I found it most amusing the fellow who was accosted at the last hotel seemed to be the doorman who was dressed in such an outrageous tuxedo and bow tie that I thought he was an extra from a Jackie Chan movie. It takes a debt collector to know a debt collector and my suspicion is that if some bills aren't paid soon, then someone is going to have a very bad day indeed!_x000D_
_x000D_
Back to tho zoo. We eventually got there at 7:40, two hours after leaving the hotel. Here we waited another 40 minutes with other irate customers in line 4 of the ticketing window to redeem our on-line ticket, which wasn't really a ticket but a voucher for a ticket that could only be redeemed for an available show ticket. So despite having "tickets" for the 7:30 tour we wound up with tickets to the 9:15 admission. The length of the queue to enter was astounding. You would have thought that it was an exodus from some war torn hell hole._x000D_
_x000D_
This left us both speechless as we needed to be back on the bus home by 9:45 for the reverse two hour trip. I noted that we were not alone in our frustration. So we had an ice cream, kissed our $100 good bye and considered it a donation to the poor inmates, and walked down to catch a cab, which had us back on Orchard road in twenty minutes. It was the worst experience that we have ever had here and the most uncharacteristic. We can't recommend the night safari or city tours to anyone. My next safari will by to watch Tarzan in the theatre. At least I might actually get in to the theatre._x000D_
_x000D_
Happy Travels, Salty
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
There is no doubt that you need to visit just to determine whether all the hype is justified, and believe me it is._x000D_
This is a very long busy road with literally hundreds of shops ranged on either side and is a shopping heaven for those who wish for the ostentatious and feel the need for designer bags and accessories. On the other side of this comment is the fact that should you want something, there will always be the outlet, as long as you can find it._x000D_
For me, the delight of this shopping area is the wonderful experience of people watching with their fashionable apparel alongside those of clearly a poorer poplace, however both sets of people seem to exist in a frenetic world that has little or no time for a more relaxed and enjoyable lifestyle._x000D_
Do visit, but be aware that money will only go so far and that material goods are not the solution to peace of mind, just ask the locals.
ADDRESS: Singapore, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: We went to the zoo on my Company's premium corporate card which allows 4 incl. Staff. We went on a Wednesday where it wasn't crowded nor too noisy. Even tho he map is huge but easy to navigate and there are Trams going in 4 stops cycle around the zoo. Tram tix cost $5/adult and $3/child and once bought, can be used unlimitedly. There are lots of things to see everywhere. The animals were spectacular just being themselves. A word of advice though is to get the mosquito patch for yourselves and especially your kids. You can get it from the shop at the entrance; just one sticker will do for that whole journey. For corporate cards and members, don't forget to show your card at any F&B and retail outlets to enjoy 20% off. It's really a good deal. There is a Kids area where there is a huge waterpark; really lovely but my nieces didnt bring extra clothes. Pony rides and Carousel are seen nearby and they can feed the goats for free. Somewhere nearby there is a rabbit house where you can see rabbits and guinea pigs in big caged playgrounds. Not sure when is the timing for the rabbit show, they didnt state. For timings of feeding, there are many signboards all around the zoo around each exhibit that allows people to see the animals being fed. For the showtimes, there are currently 4 shows and it's a good thing that the timings are roughly in a 1 hour or 1.5 hour gap so that we can walk over to the next one in time and yes, even tho the map is big but the shows are in a cluster so you dont have to run and travel everywhere. I believe there are 3 live enclosure where you can get to go in - butterflies, birds and reptiles. The animals are well behaved and just beautiful to watch. All in all, a lovely experience with memorable memories. We went to the River Safari next to continue the journey of discovering.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: Worth half a day of anyone's time. The wide range of exhibits, comprehensive but not overdone, tell Singapore's story from backwater fishing village to multicultural modern city. Take one of the free volunteer-led tours, for a friendly and informative starter, then wander at leisure around the beautifully airy building, which is a pleasure in itself. Entry is not expensive especially with the concessions for seniors and students. A must in Singapore.

REVIEW_TITLE: The whole experience was a bit meh :/
REVIEW_BODY: Guys I apologise in advance, my review might sound a bit negative for some of you given the amazing trip adviser rating for this attraction on this site. I am trying to remain unbiased during writing this review but I do need to highlight how miserable my day was probably due to some bad decisions I made along the way. So first and foremost if this is the first time you are getting on a cable car then yeah you will definitely like it. But bear in mind the ride is short... like really really short it kindda finishes before it starts. They will try to make you share the cable car with others and can fit upto 8 people in one cable car! Tried to do fit 6 passengers and a buggy with us during one of our journey. It was the most uncomfortable 3/4 mins ride in the 30 degrees heat. There is no aircon so yeah be prepared to be steamed in the heat. Although i must mention there were some weak air ventilation. If you are the second group on-boarding the cars you are most certainly going to be sitting facing the opposite direction of travel and going to miss the view. If thats ok with you considering the bucks you will be paying then yeah these are no big deal. Now the big mistake I made that ruined my day...i bought cable car return tickets from my hotel concierge, trying to be clever and avoid long queues but didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t realise this was actually voucher and not tickets. So when I went to the cable car station they sent us to the monorail office to collect tickets. This was about 20 mins walk through two shopping malls, then another 10 mins queue to redeem the tickets from the desk then 15 mins walk back to the harbourfront station. I would recommend you buy the tickets directly from the station and avoid all the extra hassle if you can. Now somehow while getting back to the station I lost my tickets, must have dropped somewhere, this never happened to me before. I went to the ticket desk to ask if they can help me in this situation, they basically told me to bugger off! Spoke to the tour company who issued the vouchers they werenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t helpful either. I was really surprised a big company like sentosa doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t have any system in place to assist genuine customers in this kind of situation. I had all my other papers with me showing i paid etc. How difficult was it for them to track and ticket they issued against the vouchers and block it and reissue new ones. No idea! They sympathised and was polite but basically didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t help me at all. Lesson for me get digital tickets where I can! Given I was there for few days I repurchased the tickets and went to sentosa. But didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t enjoy the whole experience Probably because I was let down a bit by this whole dramatic incident and ended up spending Ã¢â€šÂ¬132 for what a 15/20 mins cable car ride for two. A return trip will cost you $33 singapore dollars.
ADDRESS: 109 Mount Faber Road Faber Peak, Singapore 099203, Singapore

You really need to set aside quite a few hours here. We were advised to go late afternoon, so that we were there for the lights. I'm pleased we went a little earlier and spent nearly 5 hours there. Singapore lacks green spaces. If you are looking for a park in the city, Fort Canning is the place to go._x000D_

It is a hull so there are some slopes but it has some historic markers since it was the centre of governance in the 14th century and also the residence of the British governor._x000D_

REVIEW_BODY:
I am writing this review as a local who has traveled to many parts of the world, and hence am qualified to make comparisons._x000D_
_x000D_
Gardens by the Bay is the newest attraction in Singapore, and it is definitely worth it for tourists to visit. Opened just a little more than four years ago, this outdoor recreation and leisure destination boasts a 54 hectares footprint. The setting is that of a garden in a downtown area near the new Marina Bay financial district. It comprises a horticultural themed area centred round Singapore's multiracial heritage (Colonial, Malay, Chinese and Indian Gardens), Supertree structures and a ubiquitous learning and discovery spaces. These are free of charge. The other three sections, namely the OCBC Skyway and the two conservatories (Flower Dome and Cloud Forest) are ticketed. It costs $28 for entry to the two conservatories and $8 for the OCBC Skyway. The Flower Dome is home to themed exhibits throughout the year. So far, I have visited the Tulipmania (April to May) and the Orchid Extravaganza (July). The orchid display is part of the annual Singapore Garden Festival held in the last week of July. Some orchid displays continue to be exhibited through August as part of the celebrations for the National Day._x000D_
_x000D_
Gardens by the Bay is accessible by buses and train (MRT), preferably by train. The nearest MRT station is Bayfront. But be warned, the long walk to the Gardens takes about 20 to 25 minutes. In 2021, the Gardens will have a MRT station at its doorsteps. If arriving by car, the car park is near the free areas. It would take 5 to 10 minutes to walk to the conservatories. Car parking can be limited during the special displays periods. If cost is not a problem, my suggestion is to take a taxi. It might even be cheaper than parking the car, which costs $1.50 per hour for the first 5 hours, the rate being doubled thereafter. You would need to spend the whole day there if you intend to visit everything.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
This tour brought vividly to life the final surrender of the British to the Japanese on the 15th February 1942._x000D_
Living in the UK we are aware of the conflict in Europe but not very knowledgeable regarding the fall of Malaya and Singapore._x000D_
Our two young guides were able to explain how the situation developed and what life was like in the underground command centre in an accessible and interesting way. They had an in-depth knowledge of the subject and despite being assessed by their more senior colleagues spoke clearly and confidently._x000D_
The underground bunker has some confined spaces so it is recommended to book a tour in advance._x000D_
Allow time to explore the Fort Canning Park which is a haven of tranquillity in a very busy city.

REVIEW_BODY: These man-made trees are an absolutely essential stop on any trip to Singapore. They tower over the Gardens By The Bay and afford great views over the gardens, towards central Singapore and up at the Marina Bay Sands from the OCBC Skyway (which is a walkway between the main trees in central Supertree Grove, accessible by lift). Entrance to the Skyway is reasonable at $8 SGD and, although you're ostensibly limited to 15 minutes at the top, I don't know how vigorously this in enforced and you only really need 10 minutes or so to get all the views and snaps you need. If you don't care for heights or are on a really strict budget, the trees themselves are still well worth a look up close from ground level - a wonderful combination of natural beauty and human innovation.

REVIEW_BODY:
We very nearly didn't go. After a wonderful walk up the hill through Canning Park we arrived to find we needed to wait, and that the tour was longer than anticipated. We looked at each other, both thinking we'd be bored - we couldn't imagine how this could or should be more than 30 minutes at most. How wrong we were._x000D_
The Battlebox Tour isn't really about the rooms there, although they're fascinating of course. The Tour is about telling a story, the fall of Singapore, something we thought we knew but found we didn't._x000D_
It's told wonderfully well, focusing on the human side, not the logistics of war._x000D_
Highly highly recommended.

REVIEW_TITLE: See a stunningly beautiful white tiger! :)
REVIEW_BODY:
I like that the semi-open nature of Singapore Zoo allows some animals to roam around the zoo freely across the trees, so that you can get up and personal with some animals like the very cute cottontop tamarins. The highlight of Singapore Zoo for me was definitely the majestic and beautiful white tiger, which made for a stunning photograph! <3_x000D_
_x000D_
If you have a weekend free in Singapore, I highly recommend getting the 4 in 1 parkhopper special (includes admission to Singapore Zoo, River Safari, Night Safari and Jurong Bird Park). This way you save up to 50% on ticket prices than if you had purchased them all individually. You could probably explore Singapore Zoo in the morning when it's less crowded, then head to the River Safari in the afternoon followed by the Night Safari in the evening. Jurong Bird Park would need to be done the following day as it's far away from Singapore Zoo, River Safari and Night Safari, which are all clustered together in the same area._x000D_
_x000D_
You will need at least 3 hours at Singapore Zoo to be able to explore the whole place at a leisurely pace and to be able to attend some of the animal shows. The show with the sea lion was lots of fun to watch! Keep an eye out for their lovely polar bear as well. Definitely bring some water and snacks with you as it's rather expensive to buy food and drink around the zoo. Sensible walking shoes and a mosquito repellent are must-haves as well! Singapore Zoo is a fantastic solo or family day out! :)
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: More for people-watching than the surf and the sand
REVIEW_BODY:
It's not a very scenic beach, that's for sure. It is however one that Singapore had for decades and had been seared into the memories of many generations of Singaporeans. It is not the Gold Coast or even a Desaru. After all, how can it deservingly be a beach if what you see are the tankers in the distance and the occasional trash from the ships._x000D_
_x000D_
That's why it's not called a beach, but a park! Come here to see families spending time together cycling or BBQing. A place where Singaporeans and foreign workers come together to spend their weekends and enjoy really their friends' and family's company.

The walk around the Supertrees is worth it ($8 adult) for an elevated view of the gardens; the conservatories are functionally brilliant and architecturally interesting and the parkland lovely to wander through. REVIEW_TITLE: A must for WWII and British Empire History fans
REVIEW_BODY: When you step into the Battlebox, you step into the past. In its climate controlled rooms, you are taken on an excellent, step-by-step tour not only of the physical location of Malaya Command during the last few weeks of battle, but also the diary of the events leading up to the loss of Singapore. REVIEW_BODY:
This is an excellent day out and worth doing on a visit to Singapore. If you do all the attractions (Supertree Grove, OCBC Skyway and the domes - Forest and Cloud) it is an expensive outing but a worthwhile one._x000D_
_x000D_
The Supertree Grove has lots of useful information about the trees and how they contribute to environmentally sustainable functions while the skywalk provides good views of Singapore, the gardens and the Marina Bay area._x000D_
_x000D_
A short walk from the Supertree Grove are the two domes; both very different. The Flower Dome has gardens from different parts of the world and is kept interesting by wonderful life size carvings of animals made out of wood, sculptures, colourful flower beds and interesting themed garden beds. The Cloud Forest is a large mountain like structure that allows you to explore tropical highlands and see plants and ferns from tropical climates. It has the worlds tallest indoor waterfall and you descend down from the top along walkways as you explore the various tropical highlands.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
We were in Singapore from 10th to 13th February 2016 on a holiday. We were 6 families. On 11th February. we boarded Singapore Flayer. Some of our members were reluctant to board because of its rotation to a height of about 164 meters But once we were in, they had the last laugh. Experience of a life time._x000D_
_x000D_
The Singapore Flyer is a giant Ferris wheel in Singapore. Its a just coincidence that we were in the Flayer on 11th February 2016, when we were told that the Flayer carried its first paying passengers on 11 February 2008 but was opened to the public on 1 March 2008 and was officially opened on 15 April.2008._x000D_
_x000D_
The Flayer has 28 air-conditioned capsules, each able to accommodate 28 passengers As we were 12 members, we occupied a separate Capsule and enjoyed every minute of our stay inside the capsule. It was fantastic as we could see the entire City of Singapore from all angles and from all directions. We played, we laughted and enjoyed to the maximum extent._x000D_
_x000D_
Though the Flayer was moving, we never felt the rotation and we were so immersed in viewing the beautiful buildings and the beach No doubt, Its worth the money_x000D_
_x000D_
This is much safe even for senior citizens as much care is taken in evolving the flayer and the capsule.
ADDRESS: 30 Raffles Avenue, Singapore 039803, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Great Historical Window Into Old Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: I was born in Singapore in 1958, the son of a British Royal Airforce Engineer. I went to school here until I was 11. It was a very different place then and I loved it. Back in Europe I never forgot it or stopped longing for it. Although I am proud of what Singapore has achieved and that it is a more modern and successful place now, I miss the old kampong-style city. This museum brought the old Singapore back to me for a day. I am very grateful and will come back next time I visit the city.
ADDRESS: 93 Stamford Road National Museum of Singapore, Singapore 178897, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Newly done up and such a thrill
REVIEW_BODY:
We have always gone to Adventure Cove on Sentosa Island but as WWW was newly opened and much closer to where we were staying, we've decided to give it a go._x000D_
_x000D_
It was bigger and better than we thought. Everything was clean, spanking new and so looks very inviting. Good selection of slides and pools for younger children. Not too crowded- we went twice; once in a school holiday and once on a weekday and they were both fine._x000D_
_x000D_
Prices are a lot cheaper than adventure cove. Lazy river is prob not as good because it's shorter and doesn't go through sting ray pools like in adventure cove but all slides are better simply because there's less of a crowd so we did more of them! Food and drinks prices were v reasonable inside but you're allowed to leave and enter so can always go out to McDonald's nearby and bring it in._x000D_
_x000D_
It is located at the far East end of Singapore which might be difficult for some who are staying in the central areas to get to. Nearest MRT station is Pasir Ris._x000D_
_x000D_
Overall, definitely worth going.
ADDRESS: 1 Pasir Ris Close E!Hub@Downtown East, Singapore 519599, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
We visited twice once late afternoon to take in the skywalk. There was a long queue despite the late hour and it being out of season. The walk is short and you are ushered along as there is a maximum of 50 ( I think) allowed on at same time. The views are pretty good, close ups of the MBS hotel and other landmarks as well as the gardens and bits of the city plus all the ship's out to see. Try to be there after dusk when all the lights are on. Hint!!,you don't need to queue with tickets for the domes, get directed straight to the sky walk._x000D_
On another occasion we visited in the day to see the cloud mountain. It's a long walk round and you need a head for heights but we made it and saw them recreate the rain forest upper canopy with artificial mist._x000D_
_x000D_
We stopped to eat before going in the second some where the cactus were amazing. It was a bizarre experience seeing so much varied plant life in one place. Probably too much for some but we coped, and got some great photos too._x000D_
_x000D_
Well worth the money and the time it took to exprore it all, and there is more to come, and a children's area we missed out.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Well worth the money. Get both tickets for Cloud Forest and Flower Dome online for a cheaper price._x000D_
The second you step into the entrance of the Cloud Forest, you are welcomed by this gorgeous waterfall that just takes your breath away. The air inside is so fresh as you are surrounded by trees and flowers. Follow the path and it will lead you around the "mountain" in the center then to an elevator area where you can take it up to the top and walk down via two sky bridge hanging around the "mountain". Be warned that if you are scared of heights then the sky bridge might not be your thing as you can see what is below you via the walking path. As someone who is scared of heights it was really terrifying for me but the experience was amazing overall!

REVIEW_TITLE: Great for window shopping and street photography!
REVIEW_BODY:
Shopping wise, there is no doubt that Orchard Road is the place to go for those who are in Singapore for a shopping trip. Orchard Road is basically a long chain of shopping malls which are able to cater to a wide range of budgets, from your mass produced Uniqlo or H&M everyday clothing, all the way to your Louis Vuitton designer handbag. Because competition is very intense here, shopping malls often undergo renovation and changes often, so you may see a different look every time you come down to Orchard Road._x000D_
_x000D_
Even if you are not there to shop, even window shopping can be a good exercise to spend a few hours there with. However, in my opinion, Orchard Road is one of the few places in Singapore to do some great street photography. For the street photographer out there, this will be a sort of a paradise to get that gritty street angle feel. During weekends and public holidays, people will tend to dress better when going to Orchard Road._x000D_
_x000D_
If you are feeling tired and hungry from all that walking, there are plenty of food choices everywhere, and of course, do not forget to get some ice cream from the mobile ice cream stalls all along the pedestrian pavement that will provide some respite from the heat._x000D_
_x000D_
Overall, it is a good place to go if you are a first time visitor to Singapore, or if you are in Singapore specifically to do some street photography. I would actually recommend going further out of Orchard Road or elsewhere for better bargains and prices though.
ADDRESS: Singapore, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: The best of Fujianese traditional architecture, relaxing setting.
REVIEW_BODY:
This is such an easy place to visit. Just hop off the MRT at Chinese Garden & read the exit signs. Walk straight out the correct exit and you're in Chinese Garden. The 7 storey pagoda is a copy of the one in Fujian and you can walk up to the top & enjoy the view. Other notable buildings include: the double pagoda, the stone boat, several moon gates & bridges, & the floating pavilion... There are also lots of statues such as Confucius and Mulan, several different themed gardens like the zodiac animal garden with a bench and a statue dedicated to each animal in the Chinese zodiac._x000D_
Japanese Garden, built by Japanese landscape architects at the invitation of the Singaporean government to promote harmony, is very subdued and understated. It is accessed over a beautiful slightly arched bridge from Chinese Garden. The emphasis is on stone lanterns and manicured shrubs in Japanese Garden. You can budget 25% of your time for Japanese Garden. Both gardens are great for photographers and plein air painters!_x000D_
There is no queue or charge to visit the gardens._x000D_
There is no 'dress code', but Singaporeans don't visit gardens dressed in rags or skimpy outfits._x000D_
There's no ID check to enter the gardens._x000D_
There's nothing to buy and no guided tour; just bring your water bottle, hat, sun block cream. I didn't experience any annoying insects. There are plenty of informative signs._x000D_
There're a couple of impeccably clean toilets.
ADDRESS: 1 Chinese Garden Road Chinese Garden, Singapore 619795, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Great place to explore with the family. Load up on the insect repellents first!
REVIEW_BODY:
Great place to burn off the extra calories with the family! I won't tell you about the exhibits, just read the other reviews. As a local who visits this place often i will share with you the tips to get the most out of the trip._x000D_
Attire: Long pants and sneakers, sweat absorbing polo tee shirt. No short skirts and slippers or you will quickly regret it. Put on insect repellent liberally before the trip._x000D_
Timing : Avoid weekends where possible. To get the most out of this trip, be prepared to spare at least 3hrs. 4hrs is the best._x000D_
Things to bring : A tiny map light to read the map in the dark, a handheld fan, bottles of drinking water._x000D_
F&B : Food and drinks are ridiculously expensive at the Night Safari and thus i would suggest to have your dinner in town first before heading there._x000D_
Once the park is open, you can try the 7:30pm night show if you have children or skip it totally as it's not really worth cajoling and queuing up for. DO NOT take the trams at this stage unless you want to waste another 30mins queuing up for it. Walk the trails starting with wallaby trail and aim for East Lodge rest stop.After that head back towards the main entrance via Leopard and Fishing Cat trails. The whole exercise will take you about 1.5hours. Then you take the trams at the mainstation. At this point of time, there should be no or minimal queues at the tram station. Take at least 2 rounds to see everything.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
This museum is not very large, but has a very interesting way of telling Singapore's history. Some of the exhibits take the visitor through the personal journey of individual Singaporeans and uses that as a tool to explain the history of the country, spanning over a thousand years, with more focus on the last two hundred years of course. This is certainly a rather unusual way of presenting history, and made it all the more interesting._x000D_
_x000D_
For anyone with an interest in history generally or in Singapore's history particularly, this is a very good place to start. The building is nice as well, and there are couple of places to eat on site, including a fine dining restaurant and a casual cafe style place (Food for Thought) where we had a late lunch. Since there are not too many galleries, it would take about 3 - 4 hours to cover. About a 10 min walk from City Hall MRT._x000D_
_x000D_
Highly recommended for history buffs.
ADDRESS: 93 Stamford Road National Museum of Singapore, Singapore 178897, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Must Do on Any Visit to Singapore
REVIEW_BODY:
The Battlebox is the underground bunker system on top of Canning Hill that was the British Command Headquarters at the outbreak of World War Two._x000D_
_x000D_
It was here that General Percival and his allied commanders and senior staff officers planned the Defence of Singapore against Japanese invasion and where they eventually made the decision to surrender to the Japanese._x000D_
_x000D_
Today the bunker system has been reopened and tableaux with look-alike wax figures at command conferences, in the signals room and the aircraft spotting room._x000D_
_x000D_
Guided tours are S$18 and take about 90 minutes. Our guide, Joanne, had an amazing knowledge of all the events surrounding the Japanese invasion, the British Defence strategies, and the painful decision making process that lead to the surrender of what was previously thoughtt to be "impregnable Singapore". Not only did she deliver a highly informative narrative, but was able to answer even the most obscure questions with only a second's thought.
ADDRESS: 2 Cox Terrace | Fort Canning Park, Singapore 179622, Singapore

The National Orchid Garden is right in the middle of the Singapore Botanic Gardens so but the time you reach the entrance you will have seen plenty of trees, plants & flowers - but the Orchid Garden is worth the extra effort. Plenty of orchids from the subtly beautiful wild species, to the brash and tacky hybrids, to the Mist House with its mossy statues, to the Cool House with its mountain orchids and pleasant temperature._x000D_
Plenty of photo opportunities - tacky, romantic, arty and anything else you can think of involving flowers.
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Rd | Within the Singapore Botanic Gardens, Singapore 259569, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: The River - the major attractions surrounding are the drawcard
REVIEW_BODY: Singapore River is not one of the great rivers of the world (or even the region) - the point is that it centres the visitor on a variety of attractions, from Clarke Quay and Boat Quay and various river boat attractions (sight seeing/floating restaurants) in one of the most vibrant, essentially man made localities in the world. China Town is near by as is the Singapore Wheel and more eating/restaurant possibilities than any normal traveller could cope with. It is uniquely Singapore - many love it, some are unimpressed but the locality is a must see and do for any visit to Singapore. It will never disappoint.

REVIEW_TITLE: Fantastic Experience- a must do in Singapore!
REVIEW_BODY:
My husband and I visited the night safari, it is by far one of the best things to do in Singapore. We took the MRT to Ang Mo Kio station, then took the 138 bus which stopped right outside the Night Safari, River Safari and the Singapore Zoo entrances. We went without a ticket which in hindsight was maybe a mistake. There are 3 different admission times 7.15, 8.15 and 9.15. When we arrived the 7.15 admission time was fully booked so had to go for the 8.15 time. This meant we had to wait before we could go into the actual safari. Outside the safari are a couple of fast food areas and shops to browse through. They did also give us a free pass into the river safari as currently a lot of the sites were closed for renovation. It was still pretty good to see the manatees that they have there, but no boat ride unfortunately. As soon as 8.15 came you were let into the park and could either go by tram around the park or walk. As there was a big queue for the tram we decided to walk around. This was brilliant! Obviously it is very dark and spotting the animals is half the fun but walking around felt so much more of a natural experience. The Asian otters were particularly cute, being able to hear them before you could see them. The bat enclosure was also very good although not for the feint hearted. We walked halfway around, then jumped on the tram to experience the elephants, Rhinos and the other larger animals that aren't accessible by walking. We got back to the beginning and jumped on to see the first half again but on the tram. Then at halfway hopped off and walked the final bit which consisted of hyenas, Tigers and flying squirrels._x000D_
The tram took approximately 40 mins with the second half of the trip taking most of that chunk. If you wanted to walk only part of the safari, it would definitely have to be the first half. There are four trails, 2 for each half of the safari. It took us half an hour for each trail but could easily be done in 15 minutes. We finished everything at 11 but missed the show! My advice would be to buy a ticket beforehand for the 7.15 admission so you have a longer time going around all the animals.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Tryst with nature- amazingly well-maintained gardens
REVIEW_BODY: We wanted to do something light on our first day in Singapore, as we had just reached after a long bus ride from KL and only had a couple of hours to spare. We decided to go to the Botanic Gardens as it was a short taxi ride away from our hotel in Robertson Quay.The Gardens are not designed to be a tourist attraction, it is where locals go for their picnic, jog/walk/stroll or just a day out with nature.But there are parts of the gardens where you find more tourists than locals (the National Orchid Gardens for one). Be prepared to walk (a good walking shoe would help) and also carry water and food. There are many lovely areas where you could do a quick picnic. The trees look spectacular and many of them very old (60+ years). The swan lake is pretty with an interesting stone sculpture in the middle. The National Orchid Gardens charges a fee for foreigners and seemed to be the photographers' favourite. It is undoubtedly very beautiful, though i expected a little more flowers. We did not plan our trip very well, so we just walked as we pleased for a little more than 2 hours with some breaks in between. But there are attractions within the gardens, which could be more interesting for children (my 6 year old wasn't too pleased with all the walking and looking at trees!). These close early and hence it is better to plan the visit. Nevertheless, i loved the gardens and it is definitely a good stop to admire nature at its best (and also to avoid the crowds at all the other regular tourist attractions).
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Road, Singapore 259 569, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Started out as a good natural ramble from the Labrador mrt as you go up a slightly steep gradient past the Villa Samadhi with plenty of vegetation at the side. The historical significance emerges as you pass the cannon and figurines of soldiers with their artillery as it was in the defence of the island against theJapanese in the Pacific War. There's even a tunnel where artillery was stored.._x000D_
Further up it's the waterfront where you can see boats, container ships and the cable cars above. Unfortunately there are picnic grounds with barbecue pots resembling East Coast Park which mar the natural surroundings. Hopefully the groups which make use of them clear their refuse as we could see large numbers of plastic wrappers, bottles etc floating in the sea at the breakwater near where people were fishing (thought this wasn't allowed?)_x000D_
The boardwalk was good, passing a green mangrove pool, very picturesque, and delightfully, we saw a monitor lizard in the leaf litter, four monkeys on the rail of the boardwalk and a family of hens and chickens, a couple of squirrels._x000D_
You can exit at the other gate of the Labrador mrt station and walk across to the PSA building for lunch.._x000D_
It's a one hour walk in the park, not counting time spent on the Mrt and walking to the PSA building. Not as challenging and interesting as the Southern Ridges as it's a shorter walk, less steep but noisier with visitors and their food and hilarity.
ADDRESS: Labrador Villa Road Tanjong Berlayer Park, Singapore 119187, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Top Museum with Two Standout Galleries
REVIEW_BODY:
This really is a great museum. Cleverly laid out with well presented exhibits. Contrary to some other peoples comments most of it is actually not free (unless you happen to be Singaporean) but costs S$15. As a result of the need to pay the ticket desk is a bottle neck. There will be queues most afternoons to get in._x000D_
_x000D_
If you're pushed for time, and I realise what follows is subjective, there were two standout galleries for me. Start by going up the escalator and into the "Story of the Forest" exhibit. Nothing to do with Singapore it's a moving light show that feels like you're walking through a kids picture book. Really well done. And you eventually end up at the start of..._x000D_
_x000D_
...The story of Singapore Gallery. The main purpose of the museum this takes you through Singapore's history in multi-media exhibits that you can spend as long or as short a time with depending on how much detail you're after._x000D_
_x000D_
Finally, as an alternative to the pricey museum cafe, the university just over the street has a couple of excellent food courts. I'd particularly recommend "The Tea Party Express" at street level for dirt cheap, alfresco pasta dishes in a box often with a free drink.
ADDRESS: 93 Stamford Road National Museum of Singapore, Singapore 178897, Singapore

_x000D_
Recommended if you are into photography and looking for wildlife and willing to stand in the heat to find them._x000D_
_x000D_
Not recommended for those who hate hot and sticky weather and are not that fussed by these rather common but colourful fish, birds and reptiles._x000D_
_x000D_
In fairness to the facility, it is very well done - clean, well signed, well laid out, clear paths to walk on but the whole raison d'etre for me was a bit dull and not worth the trek north.

The blooms are great but also the landscaping. The VIP garden at the top (plants named after dignitaries), has some very special blooms._x000D_

REVIEW_BODY: The Singapore Night Safari is a refreshingly different way to enjoy seeing animals from usual daytime zoo visits. I went there with my family and it was a fun outing. There's an animal show before the main touring begins, which should be more attractive for the younger generation. Visitors are shown around the park in battery powered trains. Walking trails are also available. The animals themselves are quite varied and interesting to see at night. (A common lizard jumped on my head and sped off!) Points to remember: avoid rainy nights as the animals will mostly be in shelters. The trains are wheelchair friendly. There are foodshops at the Safari but the selection is somewhat limited.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Many years back I had the chance to visit the Quay in Singapore. It was a night visit but it seemed fairly low key. Not much excitement going on but it did seem the place to be if you were looking for some fun and drinks._x000D_
_x000D_
Years later I was able to come back and see how it has changed so much. The Quay has a great number of restaurants, pubs, bars and what appears to be dance clubs._x000D_
_x000D_
During the day it is fairly low key. Not much going on. In the evenings towards sunset, the place starts to pick up significantly._x000D_
_x000D_
I had a late lunch at the Hooters here with a plan to visit the Night Safari later. The Hooters seems to have changed a bit from my last visit but it is still a good time with good food. They also appear to have an outdoor seating area now._x000D_
_x000D_
Towards the end of the key closest to the Bay is the reverse bungee machine if you are into thrill seeking. At this point you can start to get a good view of the Marina Bay Sands hotel that looks like a boat on supports. Photo added._x000D_
_x000D_
It is easy to get to the Quay via taxi or MRT. The cost of entertainment and food at the Quay is mid range. No real cheap eats here. There are some photo opportunities for the FB selfie crowd. My main like about the Quay is it is clean, organized and there is little chance of getting run over like in many other venues around Asia similar to this._x000D_
_x000D_
It does rain a bit in Singapore and we nearly got caught in it. There are enough covered areas in the Quay that you are able to move around a bit or continue on with your festivities outdoors without fear of being soaked.

REVIEW_BODY: It was a unique experience visiting the ArtScience Museum at Singapore. The Museum's mission is to show how the Arts inspires Science and vice-versa. Temporary special exhibits are splendid in its organization, content and display. The special exhibit when we visited in the last week of Jan was the "Large Hadron Collider" which is exceptional in its conceptual design and portrayal. It shows how the atomic particles are charged up and collided at almost the speed of light in a bid to re-create the instant after Big Bang. Pictures/videos of how the God particle was detected are superb. Interesting immersive audio-visual on an artist's conception of the emergence of order from chaos after the Big Bang. It is a must see. The architecture of the building is unusually beautiful - it is shaped like a Lotus with Lily ponds around. The view of the surroundings is breath taking!
ATTRACTION_NAME: ArtScience Museum at Marina Bay Sands
ADDRESS: 10 Bayfront Avenue Marina Bay Sands, Singapore 018956, Singapore

The Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple is one of the oldest Hindu temples in Singapore and is believed to have been founded in 1881 by labourers from the North Indian state of Bengal. Being so far from home, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s no wonder they chose such a powerful and protective goddess to dedicate the temple to._x000D_
_x000D_
Of course, the temple has undergone extensive renovations and rebuilding since it was founded. Its most distinguishing feature, the entrance tower with intricate carvings of Hindu deities, was added in the 1980s and is actually of a South Indian design, in contrast to the templeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s North Indian heritage._x000D_
_x000D_

REVIEW_BODY: A small but comprehensive museum that takes you through the experiences of the British POWs and Singaporean civilians in Changi jail and beyond after the Japanese conquest. REVIEW_TITLE: Print your online ticket @ Spore Zoo Self Print Kiosk
REVIEW_BODY:
- went on Sunday night, 7.15pm slot._x000D_
- Came around 5pm, and there are already about 100 people queing, but the door not yet open._x000D_
- If you have booking code from online tickets, please print the ticket at singapore zoo self print ticket. No queue, and really will save your time._x000D_
- Around 5.45pm (I think), they open the entrance door, and people run to the ticket booth. Many people confused about queue line / redeemed ticket, priority, and groups._x000D_
- After you get your real ticket, stay around the ice cream shop. Thats the first queue line (line will open at 6.30pm)._x000D_
- There are 4 lines, 3 for reguler,1 for member/priority. Many people walked on the right side where there is a sign TRAM 4 and 5, its for groups, and ticket with tram express with multi language, extra pay for this. This line also going to Food court._x000D_
- Around 6.30pm, queue line open till in front of the jeep, then you have to wait till 7pm._x000D_
- 7pm, the Fire man show. If you want to have a good view, queue at 1 line ( left side near jeep) or sitting area at the chicken restaurant beside ticket booth._x000D_
- After the fire show, then the night safari finally open._x000D_
- After they scanned your ticket, there are 3 options: go left to the walking trail, go straight to the tram queue (the bamboo line), or go right to the animal show._x000D_
- queuing tram was not bad, because i was early._x000D_
- tram came every 5 or 10 minutes, and each time, 3 tram x 6 or 8 seat and 4 persons each seat. Tram experience was good, although not every animal can be seen. No use to take picture as it is too dark. No flash are allowed. You can only ride 1 time, if you want more, you have to queue again._x000D_
- queuing line to the animal show is near the Tram 4 and 5 station. Long queue but not as long as the entrance and tram._x000D_
- show was good, and the amphetheathre can fit many people._x000D_
_x000D_

REVIEW_BODY: As a child growing up in Malaysia, I often heard stories from my dad about the Japanese occupation of Malaya & Singapore during WW11 but little did I realised how much emotions that this visit to the old Changi Prison and War Memorial had evoked. REVIEW_TITLE: Great place for Art lovers & families
REVIEW_BODY: I'm not an art or museum person but it's the second time that I went to National Gallery Singapore. It is situated in the old Supreme Court. The architecture is nice. There are cafes and restaurants in it. I went on a Saturday and it is open from 10am-10pm which is the only museum that I ever knew that has such long opening hours, so that you have sufficient time to complete everything in 1 day (I didn't). It's good for couples to go together and view the paintings and artwork and spend some quiet time enjoying them. It's a great place for the children to have fun in the children's museum and try the art & craft. It's definitely a place for people who love to take photos. We would definitely visit again. It's near to City Hall MRT station for people who don't drive. The whole place is air conditioning. So bring a jacket along, in case.

REVIEW_BODY:
There is a direct (air conditioned!) underground walkway from the nearest MRT station (Bayfront) to here - it is so easy to follow the signs! As you come out, there is a ticket office right there; buy the tickets to the two domes together to save money._x000D_
We didn't take the offer to use a shuttle because we enjoyed walking around. The grounds are just as spectacular as the domes and the giant trees!_x000D_
If you come in the morning (10 - 11 am latest), you have more chance to be lucky with the weather because the thunderstorms usually begin at around 1 pm (at least in December). Head straight for the Sky Walk (only $8) and if you are coming at 10, you usually don't need to wait in line. You can only buy tickets to the Sky Walk at the actual entrance (or online I think). Because we were early, we didn't even have a time limit and there were not too many people up there._x000D_
_x000D_
The two domes are absolutely stunning. We couldn't get enough of them. The Christmas displays are beautiful and a fantastic blend of everything tropical and Christmassy._x000D_
_x000D_
My favourite place was the enchanted Secret garden in the Cloud Forest dome. It is only a small section but it is breathtakingly beautiful and serene._x000D_
_x000D_
We didn't eat here because everything was expensive. But the Orchard Road is only a few MRT stations away and there are great malls there with food courts. Or, of course, the hawkers' centres if you can handle the hot weather :)
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Smell the flowers and the trees at Singapore Botanical Gardens!
REVIEW_BODY: The Singapore Botanic Gardens is a 158-year-old tropical garden located at the heart of Singapore's shopping district -Orchard Road! It is one of three gardens, and the only tropical garden, to be honoured as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Its National Orchid Garden houses the largest orchid collection of 1,200 species and 2,000 hybrids. Its Admission free and opwns from 5 am to 12 midnite. Always a great place to walk after work or simply "smell the flowers" after a long and tiring day of shopping when in Singapore!
