REVIEW_BODY:
We visited Gardens by the Bay a couple of weeks ago. A local recommended we go in the evening just before sunset, but we arrived a little late at 7pm, just in time to meander our way around to the Supertree Grove for the 7.45pm light show. This place is a photographer's paradise so we snapped a few pics of the gardens and views. The light show was impressive, viewable from many vantage points. We found many visitors lying on the ground immediately below the Supertrees, looking straight up. We were lucky to have a clear and breezy evening - bliss! After the show, we went to the Cloud Forest conversatory (you will need to buy tickets to access some of the attractions). It's a cool, moist rainforest-emulating attraction. The regular mistings make the floor quite wet but not slippery. You will start by taking the elevator to the top of the 35m tall 'mountain' and then make your way down either by walking or via the elevators. My friend and I both enjoyed the attraction and think it was definitely worth a visit._x000D_
_x000D_
Caution: This attraction features elevated viewing and walkways so it may not be suitable for people with acrophobia or vertigo.

REVIEW_BODY:
The park itself was quite interesting but we had a major disappointment with the "major attraction" - the Creatures Of The Night Show. At the ticket desk we asked whether there was space on the 21:30 show, we were assured that there was and so we bought tickets. In the queue to enter the park the electronic billboard displayed the timings for the show: 19:30, 20:30, 21:30, and 22:30. Once we got in (queue was under 5 min) we were told rather rudely that the 21:30 show was full. So we asked when we should arrive for the 22:30 and were bluntly told that there was no 22:30 show. We were really disappointed and were met with no sympathy, told that that show was only on certain days, despite the billboard outside showing no information to that end._x000D_
The safari was decent but the mood was spoiled by the disappointment._x000D_
They offer a tram with an English speaking commentary but the queue was long for that and took up half our time there at the park. There are walking trails available which I would recommend as there's less people in your way and you can avoid the noisy people on the tram too.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
While there are modernization of Chinatown, please look at the back streets and quaint shops. Traditional methods are still there, if you can find it. If there were no re-painting or clean up, the place would have looked unhygienic and unsightly and possibly awful._x000D_
What the Singapore government had done was to spruce up the place and maintaining the old charm. Being one who has visited Chinatown numerous times per year, it is still a treat going back._x000D_
Along Smith Street, there is a traditional dim sum restaurant. $2 chicken rice, and this general shop selling everything which you need._x000D_
further down there is an organic food place and the menu changes everyday. They are run by a family passed down by traditions._x000D_
In the food centre, 2nd floor, there are again lots of traditional food stalls, look for the chee cheong fun, claypot rice and also chwee kueh shops!
ADDRESS: Crot | Trengganu, Singapore 048942, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Our favorite exhibit was the Cloud Forest Dome
REVIEW_BODY: We all enjoyed the Cloud Forest the best. You walk in to a magnificent waterfall falling down about 5 stories. It was close to 95* outside and you could really cool off by the misty falls. You walk in a circular route up a ramp with a gentle incline for about 3 levels and then take an elevator to the top floor. On the entire walk up the ramp you could look at plants and trees on both sides. As you got higher you looked to the outside of the dome and saw Marina Bay Sands Hotel, the big ferris wheel, the inner bay and so much more! It was great fund looking out over the top of the waterfall. You returned to ground level via another ramp and escalators. For people with strollers or wheelchairs it was all accessible for elevators.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: Even though we went to Singapore Zoo on a Saturday and the place was packed with children, the Zoo is large enough to offer everybody an amazing time. We took a Grab (the most popular transport application in South East Asia), with a very good cost of 19 SGD (Singapore Dollars), considering that the Zoo is pretty far away from the city center. For the return we decided to take a shuttle which takes you directly to a MRT station, for only 1 SGD. The shuttle station is right in front of the Zoo entrance so it canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t be missed. The Zoo itself is great and indeed itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a must-see, not only for the animals, but also for the charming park, with lots of vegetation and entertaining pavillions. I just loved the dragon themed zone, related to Game of Thrones, right at the entrance. There are plenty of food choices inside the Zoo, so you could definetely spend a whole day inside. Seeing how Singapore, the city of the future itself looks like, I would have expected a bit more technology put in the way the information about the animals is provided, the best example would be the screen that shows you how a piton detects its prey, by measuring the body temperature of the visitors walking in front if the screen. Brilliant! There is a mini-bus inside the Zoo, which takes the visitors from one place to another, but you can skip it. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s an extra 5 SGD and itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s no fun. It should be free for all visitors. Buy an online ticket, you can avoid long queues, especially if youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re going on a weekend day. You donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t need to print it, just show it on your phone.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
I love the open and interactive concept of Singapore Bird Park. It the oldest wildlife park in Singapore, I have fond memories of my visits during school outings and I still enjoy the tranquil park 30 years later._x000D_
_x000D_
The birds look really happy, chirping away loudly with plenty of room to expand their wings in the aviary with many storeys high netting and lots of real matured trees and flowering plants. The parakeets, cockatoos, lories are not shy to fly down close to humans._x000D_
_x000D_
//In the mid- to late 1990s, staff realised they should not be making the birds do stunts that a human could do._x000D_
_x000D_
The birds were then trained to showcase their natural abilities instead, such as swooping above the audience's heads or engaging in cheeky banter with the presenter.//

REVIEW_BODY: We took the MRT to promenade and walked to the ticket centre just opposite The Marina Bay Sands. We bought our tickets for the tram ride and tickets for entries to both domes. We decided to take the tram to the domes as we have visited the Gardens before and it was so hot. We visited the Flower Dome where there was the most magnificent display of tulips. Go up the path where the cacti are to get a great view over the display. Don't forget to look at the amazing sculptures. Next we went up the elevator inside one of the trees and walked along the walkway for a great view over the gardens and towards the Bay. Next we cooled off in the Cloud Dome. Go right to the top to see the insect eating plants. Photo opportunities in front of the waterfall at the bottom and behind the waterfall at the top. Return at night and watch the dazzling light display as the trees light up. The bridge from the Marina Bay Sands provides an excellent viewpoint.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: A reason for Garden lovers to go to Singapore
REVIEW_BODY:
Gardens by the bay is a destination not just an attraction. It is worth going to Singapore just to go to the gardens. Although the big enclosed domes are the highlight the surrounding, mostly tropical, gardens show the diversity of trees, palms and plants in a magnificent setting._x000D_
The flower dome has a huge array of plants, mostly in flower, from all over the world and is set out in countries and regions. The cloud rain forest dome is a little more specific as most of the plants are from higher altitude, cooler tropical area and has numerous more "indoor" types of plants. A large diverse array of orchards adds much of the colour in there along with gesneriads and other exotica._x000D_
There are flash more expensive places to eat but my preference is the food market area near the children's playground - satay is great._x000D_
If your love plants, plan on seeing this over two days._x000D_
A must see in Singapore.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Well designed and thought out zoo
REVIEW_BODY: A great zoo that is trying to balance education, protection, awareness and income. That is a difficult task when a zoo can invoke so many emotions and views. At Singapore Zoo the barriers between you and the animals are natural/man made with no cages or bars in sight. There are some Perspex screens but there are other view points of the same animals without those barriers. The zoo is accessible - for all age groups and abilities - with guided tours available. The breakfast with the Orangutans, whilst can be viewed as a commercial process, involves education and awareness to get people of all ages and backgrounds aware of their current plight. A place we would return again and recommend to others...even those who may not have it on their list of things to do in Singapore.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Despite having lived in Singapore for 17 years, this was my first visit to the Marina Barrage._x000D_
_x000D_
It was interesting but could have been much better. Good historical focus - the kampong era with its floods and droughts to the fledgling country in the 60's and Lee Kwan Yew's inspiration to do away with the old and in with the new. In all he did - he did with passion - and that included cleaning up the Singapore and Kallang Rivers, then heavily polluted. The birth of reservoirs and the road to Singapore's water self sufficiency. In front of us were a group of Hong Kong secondary or college students so sat in on their presentation. Pleased I did as the mechanical model was fairly useless without an explanation. Moved on to the next room which dealt with reclamation - guide poorly presented the topic. Said reclamation started by pouring soil in and covering it with sea water - living here - I do hope not. Told the students reclamation was common in Singapore as opposed to Hong Kong - not so - they are experts in reclaiming from the sea too. For all her faults - I did learn how the barrage operates and some water management points._x000D_
_x000D_
If your tour individually it's not particularly stimulating, especially if your not based in Singapore or have a particular local interest. Nice views of the barrage from the roof and nice artwork in forecourt._x000D_
_x000D_
Worth a visit but limit your expectations!
ADDRESS: 8 Marina Gardens Drive Marina Barrage, Singapore 018951, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Located in Kranji far from the touristy areas, this is a sobering site. A worthy memorial, especially to those who fought during WWII. There is no fee for entry and parking is free. This site can also be reached via metro (Kranji metro station). Not the best sight for small kids. Best to visit in the morning or early evening as it can get hot if there's no cloud cover._x000D_
_x000D_
It's a peaceful spot where many fallen soldiers have been laid to rest, yet face the north as if still guarding the approaches to Singapore. There are listing books kept in a small open vault in the center of the memorial if wanting to check for a name._x000D_
_x000D_
The site is well-kept and an important reminder of what took place here. Came here on the Singapore Walks Battle of Singapore tour. This was the final stop and the right way to end the tour._x000D_
_x000D_
Note; There are no facilities on site (e.g. bathrooms, vendors, etc.), so come prepared.
ADDRESS: 9 Woodlands Road, Singapore 738656, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: The Battlebox is a fabulous re-discovery (1988) and restoration (2016). Dug out under a grassy hill in 1932 it was used by the British prior to the fall of Singapore and formed part of what was then Fort Canning but now a testimony to Singapore's WW2 history. It is a must visit for anyone and the guides are very well-learned - we had Jerome who was a very young Singaporean with a wealth of knowledge and history to pass on to the tour participants. The rarely seen videos of the time are enthralling. You will walk out knowing more than you realised or thought you knew. Do yourself a favour.............go there.
ADDRESS: 2 Cox Terrace | Fort Canning Park, Singapore 179622, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: About as open as a zoo could get
REVIEW_BODY:
Great zoo, most of the enclosures are open air so the animals aren't boxed in. They have designed it really well and the scenery and plant life is wonderful too. The staff are very professional and knowledgeable._x000D_
Saw the elephant show. I'm really not keen on animals performing tricks for a crowd (my wife wanted to see this), but it was quite well done. The elephants seemed to have a good relationship with their trainers and they seemed comfortable with the performance. It was a very well organised show with a very detailed routine, which must of required a lot of practise....I just don't really think it's right. But that's just my personal view. They did all seem happy enough. They seemed to have similar shows with other animals._x000D_
So in summary, great zoo, very well kept, I just don't feel the need to make the animals perform.

REVIEW_TITLE: A wonderful taste of South India in Singapore ...
REVIEW_BODY:
This is the oldest Hindu temple in Singapore, dating from 1827, though most of it was built in the 1860s, and it was last restored six years ago. It can be found in Chinatown, not too far from the Chinatown MRT station._x000D_
_x000D_
I would thoroughly recommend visiting it as it has some very colourful ceiling paintings and sculptures, and is open from 7 a.m. to midday and then again from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. We were lucky enough to see many devotees worshipping and even a small procession of musicians under a brightly-coloured umbrella. People were quite friendly and we took care not to intrude too much on their worship._x000D_
_x000D_
Dress respectfully, remove your shoes, and remember to display the small sticker you will be given when you pay to use a camera - about 3 Singapore dollars, and well worth it. It might be worth taking some wet wipes to clean your feet afterwards - we forgot, but the floors were reasonably clean!
ADDRESS: 244 South Bridge Road Sri Mariamman Temple, Singapore 058793, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
In Singapore, there are just a few "attractions" that are free...absolutely no admission charges!_x000D_
If you would like to visit this beautiful, elegant and historic building, go to the Welcome Centre just next to the City Hall exit and ask for a free guided tour. You will be briefed on the history of Singapore and her link to this 150+ year-old cathedral, and you will be led to the various points of interest inside and around the building. And perhaps, you may be taken to one of the best-kept secret parts of the cathedral!

REVIEW_BODY:
A short trip from town to the Singapore Zoo's Night Safari is well worth the trip. If in a group, would highly recommend taking a taxi, as it will be comparative cost to MRT tickets, but much faster._x000D_
You should also book your tickets online as they allot entry times to a limited number of guests, starting at 7:15pm and allotting entry hourly after then. You will need to line up to enter, and there is always lots of people and tour groups this early._x000D_
The eateries there have a generous selection of meals without being to over the top in price._x000D_
Pro tip: Don't go on the trams first - everyone else is going to do that. Do the walking portion first, then go on the Tram.

REVIEW_BODY:
We always love going to the Botanic gardens when away and visited those in Singapore (which were excellent). We then decided to visit Gardens by the Bay, expecting it to be a bit of fun but nothing much in terms of the botanicals side. To be fair, if you simply looked round the outdoor gardens, this would be true - the iconic tree structures are stunning and the trunks are all plant walls, but it's more the novelty and the design that's interesting; the heritage gardens and other small gardens are showing signs of neglect (assumption being that most guests are simply interested in the trees and the dome so they're not maintaining the smaller gardens). Regardless, the mini gardens are not worth specifically visiting, but the domes were something else altogether. The flower dome we spent hours in wandering around the meticulously maintained plants. The other dome was a huge plant wall which is all about the mass of the structure and the overall impression of the plants but is no less breathtaking._x000D_
_x000D_
A few tips: the gardens are free other than the domes, but those are well worth the money. The domes are better viewed during the day but the trees have a night time light show so consider two visits. There is a hawker centre there doing good, reasonable value food, but it's a bit off the main route. The domes are temperature controlled so a welcome respite on a hot day.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: We spent an entire day at Gardens by the bay in July 2017 and then went back for a second day, plus returned at night to see it all lit up. This is truly an amazing place, do yourself a favour and take the little train first up, it takes you around the exterior of the gardens, giving you a fast track look around and giving a commentary as you go, . Second thing, be prepared for a long day out, there's plenty of food/ drinks available so no problem there, but do wear walking shoes and be aware it's HOT always very hot! The domes are absolutely awe inspiring, we spent hours inside taking pics, there are hordes of people, but you never feel crowded so relax and enjoy, my fav was the flower dome, it's just so colourful and magical, search for the driftwood sculptures that are blended in amongst the displays, they're amazing, hubby S fav was the cloud forest, ever 2 hours ( I think) they release mist into the dome to replicate the plants natural,climate, this is simply stunning to witness so make sure you stick around long enough to see it, the cloud dome is a little like being in Jurassic park, you will never see anything quite like this amazing park. When you head outside,, go to the artificial 'living' trees, OMG, they are ginormous, spectacular and beautiful, especially at night! Pay the money to go on the air walk at night, it's breathtaking! The whole park is absolutely huge, so please take the time to see it all, there's a great water park for the kids to cool off, and it's a day you won't forget!
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

This place place is one of the famous areas in singaphore and It called Clarke Quay_x000D_
because was named after Sir Andrew Clarke, Singapore's second Governor and Governor of the Straits Settlements from 1873 to 1875, who played a key role in positioning Singapore as the main port for the Malay states of Perak, Selangor and Sungei Ujong. This area are five blocks of restored warehouses house various restaurants and nightclubs. There are also moored Chinese junks (tongkangs) that have been refurbished into floating pubs and restaurants. This area fantastic for eating because variety of cusines with cool night life.Also, there are cool shopping mall in this area. you must see._x000D_

REVIEW_BODY:
In general, I would say the whole experience of being at the gardens was just average. Paid to go in the flower dome and cloud forest. They are currently having the orchid exhibition at the flower dome. Nice orchids but too limited in quantity in my opinion and it's mostly all concentrated in the middle of the dome on a one way traffic lane. Difficult to take pictures as you will be blocking the traffic flow. Everything has to be done quick. The other side of the flower dome is like a desert with just cactus exhibition. Cloud forest was basically just a mini forest with a giant waterfall at the entrance. There were a few fossils and glaciers monuments to look at the the ground level and also video clips on natural disasters I think. Too many people were packed at the video section so we decided to skip._x000D_
_x000D_
The positive side to these two domes is that they are both well air-conditioned and it was very nice to be inside. Nice change to the heat and humidity at the free zone outside. And you get to go in and out the domes as many times you want (within the day of ticket purchase). Just need to get a stamp on your wrist._x000D_
_x000D_
There is a little cafe/restaurant inside the flower dome. Did not get a chance to look at the menu and environment as they were having a private event when we were there._x000D_
_x000D_
Overall just an average experience. Will go to the flower dome again in the future only if there's a specialty exhibition (I.e. Tulips exhibition or during festive season when the domes are decorated). Other than that, I would give the domes a pass.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Extremely well done and so informative
REVIEW_BODY:
Situated just across the road from Maxwell Hawker Centre, this Gallery was a real eye opener for me. It is extremely well put together and very informative._x000D_
_x000D_
I discovered so many facts that I had no idea of prior to my visit. I'm in awe of the foresight and superior skills of those charged with the responsibility of urban planning in Singapore._x000D_
_x000D_
Nothing seems to be done 'on the hop', but is planned many years in advance so that everyone has a vision about what they are aiming for. This is a lesson which the planners in my country could take on board instead of having to act at the last minute because they hadn't looked far enough into the future when they released land for building or built roads, etc.

REVIEW_BODY: We enjoyed walking the whole length of the Southern Ridges. It was raining most of the way but we wore waterproof jackets and got on with it. The views were still fab, and it was amazing to see city high rise blocks right up next to the rainforest. I thought the walk might be more challenging but it was clearly marked paths and boardwalks all the way with not much steep gradient. There were signs in the forest saying what to do if you encounter monkeys, but sadly we did not. This impressive white-faced building overlooks the Padang. The Foundation Stone dates from 1834 and, like most other buildings of the period was on the site chosen by Sir Stamford Raffles. REVIEW_BODY: We visited the Gardens by the Bay in July 2017, we spent two days wandering around this magical place, the cloud dome was my husbands fav spot, ( I was by no means disappointed)! The domes are lovely and cool, hordes of people, but it's very easy to get around, so,you don't feel hemmed in at all, wear good walking shoes, make the climb up the inner structure, keep an eye peeled for the driftwood masterpieces that are placed in amongst the gardens, they are so beautiful, and it's easy to miss them if you only have a fleeting glance around. What they have created there is truly amazing and an absolute high lite of our stay in beautiful Singapore!

REVIEW_TITLE: Grab your walking shoes and have a great day at the Zoo
REVIEW_BODY:
The Singapore Zoo is in a shared complex with several other attractions, but due to the size and amount of area, it covers I would not recommend trying to see anything other than the Zoo in one day._x000D_

I took several 9-year-olds, both boys and girls and there was enough diversity to keep them all engaged. The sea lion and elephant shows were the biggest hits. The sea lion theatre is covered but arrive early to the elephant show to secure a covered seat._x000D_

Well worth the trip.
